title: Configuration
heading: execution.isolation.strategy
content: this property indicates which isolation strategy

title: Configuration
heading: execution.isolation.strategy
content: executes with, one of the following two choices:

title: Configuration
heading: execution.isolation.strategy
content: it executes on a separate thread and concurrent requests are limited by the number of threads in the thread-pool

title: Configuration
heading: execution.isolation.strategy
content: it executes on the calling thread and concurrent requests are limited by the semaphore count

title: Configuration
heading: Thread or Semaphore
content: the default, and the recommended setting, is to run

title: Configuration
heading: Thread or Semaphore
content: commands executed in threads have an extra layer of protection against latencies beyond what network timeouts can offer.

title: Configuration
heading: Thread or Semaphore
content: generally the only time you should use semaphore isolation for

title: Configuration
heading: Thread or Semaphore
content: s is when the call is so high volume (hundreds per second, per instance) that the overhead of separate threads is too high; this typically only applies to non-network calls.

title: Configuration
heading: Thread or Semaphore
content: netflix api has 100+ commands running in 40+ thread pools and only a handful of those commands are not running in a thread - those that fetch metadata from an in-memory cache or that are fa

title: Configuration
heading: Thread or Semaphore
content: for more information about this decision.

title: Configuration

content:
default valuethread (see executionisolationstrategy.thread)
possible valuesthread, semaphore
default propertyhystrix.command.default.execution.isolation.strategy

how to set instance default:
// to use thread isolation
hystrixcommandproperties.setter()
   .withexecutionisolationstrategy(executionisolationstrategy.thread)
// to use semaphore isolation
hystrixcommandproperties.setter()
   .withexecutionisolationstrategy(executionisolationstrategy.semaphore)

title: Configuration
heading: execution.isolation.semaphore.maxConcurrentRequests
content: this property sets the maximum number of requests allowed to a

title: Configuration
heading: execution.isolation.semaphore.maxConcurrentRequests
content: if this maximum concurrent limit is hit then subsequent requests will be rejected.

title: Configuration
heading: execution.isolation.semaphore.maxConcurrentRequests
content: the logic that you use when you size a semaphore is basically the same as when you choose how many threads to add to a thread-pool, but the overhead for a semaphore is far smaller and typically the executions are far faster (sub-millisecond), otherwise you would be using threads.

title: Configuration
heading: execution.isolation.semaphore.maxConcurrentRequests
content: for example, 5000rps on a single instance for in-memory lookups with metrics being gathered has been seen to work with a semaphore of only 2.

title: Configuration
heading: execution.isolation.semaphore.maxConcurrentRequests
content: the isolation principle is still the same so the semaphore should still be a small percentage of the overall container (i.e. tomcat) thread pool, not all of or most of it, otherwise it provides no protection.

title: Configuration
heading: Circuit Breaker
content: the circuit breaker properties control behavior of the

title: Configuration
heading: circuitBreaker.enabled
content: this property determines whether a circuit breaker will be used to track health and to short-circuit requests if it trips.

title: Configuration
heading: circuitBreaker.requestVolumeThreshold
content: this property sets the minimum number of requests in a rolling window that will trip the circuit.

title: Configuration
heading: circuitBreaker.requestVolumeThreshold
content: for example, if the value is 20, then if only 19 requests are received in the rolling window (say a window of 10 seconds) the circuit will not trip open even if all 19 failed.

title: Configuration
heading: circuitBreaker.sleepWindowInMilliseconds
content: this property sets the amount of time, after tripping the circuit, to reject requests before allowing attempts again to determine if the circuit should again be closed.

title: Configuration
heading: circuitBreaker.errorThresholdPercentage
content: this property sets the error percentage at or above which the circuit should trip open and start short-circuiting requests to fallback logic.

title: Configuration
heading: circuitBreaker.forceOpen
content: , forces the circuit breaker into an open (tripped) state in which it will reject all requests.

title: Configuration
heading: circuitBreaker.forceClosed
content: , forces the circuit breaker into a closed state in which it will  allow requests regardless of the error percentage.

title: Configuration
heading: metrics.rollingPercentile.bucketSize
content: this property sets the maximum number of execution times that are kept per bucket. if more executions occur during the time they will wrap around and start over-writing at the beginning of the bucket.

title: Configuration
heading: metrics.rollingPercentile.bucketSize
content: for example, if bucket size is set to 100 and represents a bucket window of 10 seconds, but 500 executions occur during this time, only the last 100 executions will be kept in that 10 second bucket.

title: Configuration

heading: ThreadPool Properties
content: the following properties control the behavior of the thread-pools that hystrix commands execute on.  please note that these names match those in

title: Configuration
heading: ThreadPool Properties
content: most of the time the default value of 10 threads will be fine (often it could be made smaller).

title: Configuration
heading: ThreadPool Properties
content: to determine if it needs to be larger, a basic formula for calculating the size is:

title: Configuration
heading: ThreadPool Properties
content: requests per second at peak when healthy

title: Configuration
heading: ThreadPool Properties
content: 99th percentile latency in seconds + some breathing room

title: Configuration
heading: ThreadPool Properties
content: see the example below to see how this formula is put into practice.

title: Configuration
heading: ThreadPool Properties
content: the general principle is keep the pool as small as possible, as it is the primary tool to shed load and prevent resources from becoming blocked if latency occurs.

title: Configuration
heading: ThreadPool Properties
content: netflix api has 30+ of its threadpools set at 10, two at 20, and one at 25.

title: Configuration
heading: ThreadPool Properties
content: the above diagram shows an example configuration in which the dependency has no reason to hit the 99.5th percentile and therefore it cuts it short at the network timeout layer and immediately retries with the expectation that it will get median latency most of the time, and will be able to accomplish this all within the 300ms thread timeout.

title: Configuration
heading: ThreadPool Properties
content: if the dependency has legitimate reasons to sometimes hit the 99.5th percentile (such as cache miss with lazy generation) then the network timeout will be set higher than it, such as at 325ms with 0 or 1 retries and the thread timeout set higher (350ms+).

title: Configuration
heading: ThreadPool Properties
content: the thread-pool is sized at 10 to handle a burst of 99th percentile requests, but when everything is healthy this threadpool will typically only have 1 or 2 threads active at any given time to serve mostly 40ms median calls.

title: Configuration
heading: ThreadPool Properties
content: when you configure it correctly a timeout at the

title: Configuration
heading: ThreadPool Properties
content: layer should be rare, but the protection is there in case something other than network latency affects the time, or the combination of connect+read+retry+connect+read in a worst case scenario still exceeds the configured overall timeout.

title: Configuration
heading: ThreadPool Properties
content: the aggressiveness of configurations and tradeoffs in each direction are different for each dependency.

title: Configuration
heading: ThreadPool Properties
content: you can change configurations in real-time as needed as performance characteristics change or when problems are found, all without the risk of taking down the entire app if problems or misconfigurations occur.

title: Home
heading: What Is Hystrix?
content: in a distributed environment, inevitably some of the many service dependencies will fail.  hystrix is a library that helps you control the interactions between these distributed services by adding latency tolerance and fault tolerance logic.  hystrix does this by isolating points of access between the services, stopping cascading failures across them, and providing fallback options, all of which improve your system

title: Home
heading: History of Hystrix
content: hystrix evolved out of resilience engineering work that the netflix api team began in 2011.  in 2012, hystrix continued to evolve and mature, and many teams within netflix adopted it.  today tens of billions of thread-isolated, and hundreds of billions of semaphore-isolated calls are executed via hystrix every day at netflix. this has resulted in a dramatic improvement in uptime and resilience.

title: Home
heading: History of Hystrix
content: the following links provide more context around hystrix and the challenges that it attempts to address:

title: Home
heading: History of Hystrix
content: fault tolerance in a high volume, distributed system

title: Home
heading: History of Hystrix
content: performance and fault tolerance for the netflix api

title: Home
heading: History of Hystrix
content: application resilience in a service-oriented architecture

title: Home
heading: What Is Hystrix For?
content: hystrix is designed to do the following:

title: Home
heading: What Is Hystrix For?
content: give protection from and control over latency and failure from dependencies accessed (typically over the network) via third-party client libraries.

title: Home
heading: What Is Hystrix For?
content: stop cascading failures in a complex distributed system.

title: Home
heading: What Is Hystrix For?
content: fallback and gracefully degrade when possible.

title: Home
heading: What Is Hystrix For?
content: enable near real-time monitoring, alerting, and operational control.

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: applications in complex distributed architectures have dozens of dependencies, each of which will inevitably fail at some point.  if the host application is not isolated from these external failures, it risks being taken down with them.

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: for example, for an application that depends on 30 services where each service has 99.99% uptime, here is what you can expect:

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: 2+ hours downtime/month even if all dependencies have excellent uptime.

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: even when all dependencies perform well the aggregate impact of even 0.01% downtime on each of dozens of services equates to potentially hours a month of downtime

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: if you do not engineer the whole system for resilience

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: when everything is healthy the request flow can look like this:

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: when one of many backend systems becomes latent it can block the entire user request:

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: with high volume traffic a single backend dependency becoming latent can cause all resources to become saturated in seconds on all servers.

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: every point in an application that reaches out over the network or into a client library that might result in network requests is a source of potential failure.  worse than failures, these applications can also result in increased latencies between services, which backs up queues, threads, and other system resources causing even more cascading failures across the system.

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: these issues are exacerbated when network access is performed through a third-party client

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: where implementation details are hidden and can change at any time, and network or resource configurations are different for each client library and often difficult to monitor and change.

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: even worse are transitive dependencies that perform potentially expensive or fault-prone network calls without being explicitly invoked by the application.

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: network connections fail or degrade. services and servers fail or become slow. new libraries or service deployments change behavior or performance characteristics. client libraries have bugs.

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: all of these represent failure and latency that needs to be isolated and managed so that a single failing dependency can

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: t take down an entire application or system.

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: <a name="principles" /> ## what design principles underlie hystrix?

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: preventing any single dependency from using up all container (such as tomcat) user threads.

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: shedding load and failing fast instead of queueing.

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: providing fallbacks wherever feasible to protect users from failure.

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: using isolation techniques (such as bulkhead, swimlane, and circuit breaker patterns) to limit the impact of any one dependency.

title: Home
heading: What Problem Does Hystrix Solve?
content: optimizing for time-to-discovery through near real-time metrics, monitoring, and alerting

title: How-it-Works
heading: Isolation
content: hystrix employs the bulkhead pattern to isolate dependencies from each other and to limit concurrent access to any one of them.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Threads & Thread Pools
content: clients (libraries, network calls, etc) execute on separate threads. this isolates them from the calling thread (tomcat thread pool) so that the caller may

title: How-it-Works
heading: Threads & Thread Pools
content: from a dependency call that is taking too long.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Threads & Thread Pools
content: hystrix uses separate, per-dependency thread pools as a way of constraining any given dependency so latency on the underlying executions will saturate the available threads only in that pool.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Threads & Thread Pools
content: it is possible for you to protect against failure without the use of thread pools, but this requires the client being trusted to fail very quickly (network connect/read timeouts and retry configuration) and to always behave well.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Threads & Thread Pools
content: netflix, in its design of hystrix, chose the use of threads and thread-pools to achieve isolation for many reasons including:

title: How-it-Works
heading: Threads & Thread Pools
content: many applications execute dozens (and sometimes well over 100) different back-end service calls against dozens of different services developed by as many different teams.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Threads & Thread Pools
content: each service provides its own client library.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Threads & Thread Pools
content: client libraries are changing all the time.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Threads & Thread Pools
content: client library logic can change to add new network calls.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Threads & Thread Pools
content: client libraries can contain logic such as retries, data parsing, caching (in-memory or across network), and other such behavior.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Threads & Thread Pools
content: opaque to their users about implementation details, network access patterns, configuration defaults, etc.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Threads & Thread Pools
content: in several real-world production outages the determination was

title: How-it-Works
heading: Threads & Thread Pools
content: oh, something changed and properties should be adjusted

title: How-it-Works
heading: Threads & Thread Pools
content: the client library changed its behavior.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Threads & Thread Pools
content: even if a client itself doesn

title: How-it-Works
heading: Threads & Thread Pools
content: t change, the service itself can change, which can then impact performance characteristics which can then cause the client configuration to be invalid.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Threads & Thread Pools
content: transitive dependencies can pull in other client libraries that are not expected and perhaps not correctly configured.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Threads & Thread Pools
content: most network access is performed synchronously.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Threads & Thread Pools
content: failure and latency can occur in the client-side code as well, not just in the network call.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Benefits of Thread Pools
content: the benefits of isolation via threads in their own thread pools are:

title: How-it-Works
heading: Benefits of Thread Pools
content: the application is fully protected from runaway client libraries. the pool for a given dependency library can fill up without impacting the rest of the application.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Benefits of Thread Pools
content: the application can accept new client libraries with far lower risk. if an issue occurs, it is isolated to the library and doesn

title: How-it-Works
heading: Benefits of Thread Pools
content: when a failed client becomes healthy again, the thread pool will clear up and the application immediately resumes healthy performance, as opposed to a long recovery when the entire tomcat container is overwhelmed.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Benefits of Thread Pools
content: if a client library is misconfigured, the health of a thread pool will quickly demonstrate this (via increased errors, latency, timeouts, rejections, etc.) and you can handle it (typically in real-time via dynamic properties) without affecting application functionality.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Benefits of Thread Pools
content: if a client service changes performance characteristics (which happens often enough to be an issue) which in turn cause a need to tune properties (increasing/decreasing timeouts, changing retries, etc.) this again becomes visible through thread pool metrics (errors, latency, timeouts, rejections) and can be handled without impacting other clients, requests, or users.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Benefits of Thread Pools
content: beyond the isolation benefits, having dedicated thread pools provides built-in concurrency which can be leveraged to build asynchronous facades on top of synchronous client libraries (similar to how the netflix api built a reactive, fully-asynchronous java api on top of hystrix commands).

title: How-it-Works
heading: Benefits of Thread Pools
content: in short, the isolation provided by thread pools allows for the always-changing and dynamic combination of client libraries and subsystem performance characteristics to be handled gracefully without causing outages.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Benefits of Thread Pools
content: despite the isolation a separate thread provides, your underlying client code should also have timeouts and/or respond to thread interrupts so it can not block indefinitely and saturate the hystrix thread pool.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Drawbacks of Thread Pools
content: the primary drawback of thread pools is that they add computational overhead. each command execution involves the queueing, scheduling, and context switching involved in running a command on a separate thread.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Drawbacks of Thread Pools
content: netflix, in designing this system, decided to accept the cost of this overhead in exchange for the benefits it provides and deemed it minor enough to not have major cost or performance impact.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Cost of Threads
content: hystrix measures the latency when it executes the

title: How-it-Works
heading: Cost of Threads
content: method on the child thread as well as the total end-to-end time on the parent thread. this way you can see the cost of hystrix overhead (threading, metrics, logging, circuit breaker, etc.).

title: How-it-Works
heading: Cost of Threads
content: the netflix api processes 10+ billion hystrix command executions per day using thread isolation. each api instance has 40+ thread-pools with 5

title: How-it-Works
heading: Cost of Threads
content: 20 threads in each (most are set to 10).

title: How-it-Works
heading: Cost of Threads
content: being executed at 60 requests-per-second on a single api instance (of about 350 total threaded executions per second per server):

title: How-it-Works
heading: Cost of Threads
content: at the median (and lower) there is no cost to having a separate thread.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Cost of Threads
content: percentile there is a cost of 3ms for having a separate thread.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Cost of Threads
content: percentile there is a cost of 9ms for having a separate thread. note however that the increase in cost is far smaller than the increase in execution time of the separate thread (network request) which jumped from 2 to 28 whereas the cost jumped from 0 to 9.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Cost of Threads
content: percentile and higher for circuits such as these has been deemed acceptable for most netflix use cases for the benefits of resilience achieved.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Cost of Threads
content: for circuits that wrap very low-latency requests (such as those that primarily hit in-memory caches) the overhead can be too high and in those cases you can use another method such as tryable semaphores which, while they do not allow for timeouts, provide most of the resilience benefits without the overhead. the overhead in general, however, is small enough that netflix in practice usually prefers the isolation benefits of a separate thread over such techniques.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Semaphores
content: you can use semaphores (or counters) to limit the number of concurrent calls to any given dependency, instead of using thread pool/queue sizes. this allows hystrix to shed load without using thread pools but it does not allow for timing out and walking away. if you trust the client and you only want load shedding, you could use this approach.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Semaphores
content: when hystrix retrieves fallbacks it always does so on the calling tomcat thread.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Semaphores
content: then hystrix will use semaphores instead of threads to limit the number of concurrent parent threads that invoke the command.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Semaphores
content: you can configure both of these uses of semaphores by means of dynamic properties that define how many concurrent threads can execute. you should size them by using similar calculations as you use when sizing a threadpool (an in-memory call that returns in sub-millisecond times can perform well over 5000rps with a semaphore of only 1 or 2

title: How-it-Works
heading: Semaphores
content: if a dependency is isolated with a semaphore and then becomes latent, the parent threads will remain blocked until the underlying network calls timeout.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Semaphores
content: semaphore rejection will start once the limit is hit but the threads filling the semaphore can not walk away.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Request Collapsing
content: is the abstract parent) with which you can collapse multiple requests into a single back-end dependency call.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Request Collapsing
content: the following diagram shows the number of threads and network connections in two scenarios: first without and then with request collapsing (assuming all connections are

title: How-it-Works
heading: Request Collapsing
content: within a short time window, in this case 10ms).

title: How-it-Works
heading: Why Use Request Collapsing?
content: use request collapsing to reduce the number of threads and network connections needed to perform concurrent

title: How-it-Works
heading: Why Use Request Collapsing?
content: executions. request collapsing does this in an automated manner that does not force all developers of a codebase to coordinate the manual batching of requests.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Global Context (Across All Tomcat Threads)
content: the ideal type of collapsing is done at the global application level, so that requests from

title: How-it-Works
heading: Global Context (Across All Tomcat Threads)
content: on any tomcat thread can be collapsed together.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Global Context (Across All Tomcat Threads)
content: for example, if you configure a

title: How-it-Works
heading: Global Context (Across All Tomcat Threads)
content: to support batching for any user on requests to a dependency that retrieves movie ratings, then when any user thread in the same jvm makes such a request, hystrix will add its request along with any others into the same collapsed network call.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Global Context (Across All Tomcat Threads)
content: note that the collapser will pass a single hystrixrequestcontext object to the collapsed network call, so downstream systems must need to handle this case for this to be an effective option.

title: How-it-Works
heading: User Request Context (Single Tomcat Thread)
content: to only handle batch requests for

title: How-it-Works
heading: User Request Context (Single Tomcat Thread)
content: , then hystrix can collapse requests from within a single tomcat thread (request).

title: How-it-Works
heading: User Request Context (Single Tomcat Thread)
content: for example, if a user wants to load bookmarks for 300 video objects, instead of executing 300 network calls, hystrix can combine them all into one.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Object Modeling and Code Complexity
content: sometimes when you create an object model that makes logical sense to the consumers of the object, this does not match up well with efficient resource utilization for the producers of the object.

title: How-it-Works
heading: Object Modeling and Code Complexity
content: for example, given a list of 300 video objects, iterating over them and calling

title: How-it-Works
heading: Object Modeling and Code Complexity
content: on each is an obvious object model, but if implemented naively can result in 300 network calls all being made within milliseconds of each other (and very likely saturating resources).

title: How-it-Works
heading: What Is the Cost of Request Collapsing?
content: what is the cost of request collapsing?

title: How-it-Works
heading: What Is the Cost of Request Collapsing?
content: the cost of enabling request collapsing is an increased latency before the actual command is executed. the maximum cost is the size of the batch window.

title: How-it-Works
heading: What Is the Cost of Request Collapsing?
content: if you have a command that takes 5ms on median to execute, and a 10ms batch window, the execution time could become 15ms in a worst case. typically a request will not happen to be submitted to the window just as it opens, and so the median penalty is half the window time, in this case 5ms.

title: How-it-Works
heading: What Is the Cost of Request Collapsing?
content: the determination of whether this cost is worth it depends on the command being executed. a high-latency command won

title: How-it-Works
heading: What Is the Cost of Request Collapsing?

title: How-it-Works
heading: What Is the Cost of Request Collapsing?
content: t suffer as much from a small amount of additional average latency. also, the amount of concurrency on a given command is key: there is no point in paying the penalty if there are rarely more than 1 or 2 requests to be batched together. in fact, in a single-threaded sequential iteration collapsing would be a major performance bottleneck as each iteration will wait the 10ms batch window time.

title: How-it-Works
heading: What Is the Cost of Request Collapsing?
content: if, however, a particular command is heavily utilized concurrently and can batch dozens or even hundreds of calls together, then the cost is typically far outweighed by the increased throughput achieved as hystrix reduces the number of threads it requires and the number of network connections to dependencies.

title: Metrics-and-Monitoring
heading: Motivation
content: as hystrixcommands and hystrixobservablecommands execute, they generate metrics on execution outcomes and latency.  these are very useful to operators of the system, as they give a great deal of insight into how the system is behaving.  hystrix offers metrics per command key and to very fine granularities (on the order of seconds).

title: Metrics-and-Monitoring
heading: Motivation
content: these metrics are useful both individually, and in aggregate.  getting the set of commands that executed in a request, along with outcomes and latency information, is often helpful in debugging.  aggregate metrics are useful in understanding overall system-level behavior, and are appropriate for alerting or reporting.  the

title: Metrics-and-Monitoring
heading: Metrics storage
content: when the metrics get generated, they need to get stored for some period of time before they get pushed off-box and into a different system.  the alternative is to always stream metrics directly off-box, and this is unlikely to perform well unless the volume is very low.  instead, the approach hystrix chooses is to write the metrics to in-memory data structures.  these store metrics and allow for querying at some later point.

title: Metrics-and-Monitoring
heading: Metrics storage
content: the specific data structures that store metrics changed in hystrix 1.5.0.

title: Metrics-and-Monitoring
heading: Up to 1.4.x
content: in hystrix versions up to 1.4.x, metrics are written to aggregating data structures.  a

title: Metrics-and-Monitoring
heading: Up to 1.4.x
content: captures counts of events and a

title: Metrics-and-Monitoring
heading: Up to 1.4.x
content: captures observations of quantities that have interesting distributions.  for example, command latency and collapser batch size are tracked using a

title: Metrics-and-Monitoring
heading: Up to 1.4.x
content: .  metrics are written to these data structures synchronously as the command executes.  these data structures support a rolling model, where only the most recent metrics are kept.

title: Metrics-and-Monitoring
heading: HystrixRollingNumber
content: as commands start executing, these data structures get initialized.  hystrixrollingnumbers take 2 pieces of config: number of buckets, and overall window of metrics to track.  call the number of buckets

title: Metrics-and-Monitoring
heading: HystrixRollingNumber
content: ) the bucket size (in milliseconds).  given that config, writes always go into the newest bucket, and reads go against this

title: Metrics-and-Monitoring
heading: HystrixRollingNumber
content: buckets are needed at a time, the data structure re-uses old buckets to save on memory allocation.  because all of the writes are synchronous, there

title: Metrics-and-Monitoring
heading: HystrixRollingNumber
content: s no background work that does this

title: Metrics-and-Monitoring
heading: HystrixRollingNumber
content: .  instead, one unlucky write per bucket pays the cost of doing the work of updating pointers and getting a new bucket ready for writing.  this data structure permits any threads to write, so has internal synchronization logic to allow this to occur safely, without external synchronization.

heading: HystrixRollingNumber
content: please also see those config links for an illustration of how the rolling number does bucketing.

content: the hystrixrollingpercentile is similar.  it shares the bucketing semantics of hystrixrollingnumber, and has the additional configuration of the maximum number of observations in a bucket.  reads of this data structure can be a mean or arbitrary percentile of the distribution.  in this case, the distribution is calculated over the

title: Operations
heading: How to Configure and Tune a Circuit
content: the typical approach to deploying a new circuit has been to release it into production with liberal configuration (timeouts/threads/semaphores) and then tune it down to a more strict configuration after seeing it run through a peak production cycle.

heading: When Things Are Latent
content: pairing) became latent to dynamically change properties to increase thread-pools, queues, timeouts, and so forth to

title: Operations
heading: When Things Are Latent
content: try and give it some breathing room

title: Operations
heading: When Things Are Latent
content: and get it working again. but that is the opposite of what you should do. if you configured the command correctly for a healthy system and it is now rejecting, timing out, and/or short-circuiting then you should concentrate on fixing the underlying root cause.

title: Operations
heading: When Things Are Latent
content: t make the mistake of responding by giving the command more resources that it can use up (at an extreme if you behave that way, you ddos yourself by increasing the size of thread-pools, queues, timeouts, semaphores, and the like.)

title: Operations
heading: When Things Are Latent
content: for example, imagine that you have a cluster of 100 servers each with 10 concurrent connections to a service allowed, that is: 1000 possible concurrent connections. when healthy it normally uses 200

title: Operations
heading: When Things Are Latent
content: 300 of them at any given time. if latency occurs and backs them all up, you are now using 1000 connections. 10 per box may not seem much for the client so let

title: Operations
heading: When Things Are Latent
content: s try increasing it to 20, right? most likely if 10 were saturated, 20 will become saturated as well. now you have 2000 connections held open against the back end making things even worse.

title: Operations
heading: When Things Are Latent
content: this is one of the reasons why the circuit breaker exists

title: Operations
heading: When Things Are Latent
content: on underlying systems to let them recover instead of pounding them with more requests in retry loops, hung connections, and the like.

title: Operations
heading: When Things Are Latent
content: for example, here is an example of a single dependency experiencing latency resulting in timeouts high enough to cause the circuit-breaker to trip on about one-third of the cluster. it is the only circuit in the system having health issues and hystrix is preventing it from taking other resources while it has latency problems.

title: Operations
heading: When Things Are Latent
content: in short, let the system shed load, short-circuit, timeout, and reject until the underlying system is healthy again and it will take care of itself and come back to health at the hystrix layer. hystrix is designed for exactly this scenario and the point is to reduce resource utilization by latent systems so that recovery can occur quickly by keeping most resources isolated and away from those that are hung up on a latent connection.

title: Operations
heading: What Dependency Failure Looks Like
content: the most typical type of failure in a distributed system is for a single dependency to fail or become latent while all others remain healthy. in these cases the metrics and dashboards are very obvious in showing what is happening:

title: Operations
heading: What Dependency Failure Looks Like
content: the above screenshot shows a single circuit with a 20% error rate: high enough to have impact but not enough to start tripping the circuit breakers. the other three circuits are unaffected.

title: Operations
heading: What Dependency Failure Looks Like
content: in this particular example it is actual errors, not latency, that is causing the problem

title: Operations

content: as shown by the red numbers instead of orange.

title: Operations
heading: What Dependency Failure Looks Like
content: the following charts were captured during the same incident to show the historical trend of this circuit and how it spiked in failures and fallbacks.

title: Operations
heading: Dependency Failure with Fallback
content: here is a screenshot of another incident affecting a single circuit. note that the 99.5

title: Operations
heading: Dependency Failure with Fallback
content: percentile latency is very high. that

title: Operations
heading: Dependency Failure with Fallback
content: s how long the underlying worker threads were taking to complete, which would in turn saturate the thread pools and lead to time-outs from the calling thread.

title: Operations
heading: Dependency Failure with Fallback
content: all but one machine in the cluster has the circuit breaker tripped, which accounts for most traffic being short-circuited (blue), and on the one machine still trying most requests are being timed out (orange).

title: Operations
heading: Dependency Failure with Fallback
content: note that the other circuits are healthy and the line graph on the left shows no increase in 500s being returned since this circuit is returning a fallback so users are receiving a degraded but still functional experience.

title: Operations
heading: Cascading Dependency Failures
content: this screenshot represents a failure (in this case high latency) of a single system that is heavily depended upon by many other systems and so the failure cascaded across them as well. the netflix api system had to be resilient against latency and failure not from just the single root cause but all of the systems impacted by it as well.

heading: Command Execution Hook
content:
hystrixcommandexecutionhook methodwhen hystrix calls the method
onstartbefore the hystrixinvokable begins executing
onemitwhenever the hystrixinvokable emits a value
onerrorif the hystrixinvokable fails with an exception
onsuccessif the hystrixinvokable completes successfully
onthreadstartat the start of thread execution if the hystrixinvokable is a hystrixcommand executed using the thread executionisolationstrategy
onthreadcompleteat the completion of thread execution if the hystrixinvokable is a hystrixcommand executed using the thread executionisolationstrategy
onexecutionstartwhen the user-defined execution method in the hystrixinvokable begins
onexecutionemitwhenever the user-defined execution method in the hystrixinvokable emits a value
onexecutionerrorwhen the user-defined execution method in the hystrixinvokable fails with an exception
onexecutionsuccesswhen the user-defined execution method in the hystrixinvokable completes successfully
onfallbackstartif the hystrixinvokable attempts to call the fallback method
onfallbackemitwhenever the fallback method in the hystrixinvokable emits a value
onfallbackerrorif the fallback method in the hystrixinvokable fails with an exception or does not exist when a call attempt is made
onfallbacksuccessif the fallback method in the hystrixinvokable completes successfully
oncachehitif the response to the hystrixinvokable is found in the hystrixrequestcache

title: Plugins
heading: Abstract vs. Interface
content: each of the plugins shown above exposes the base as an abstract class to be extended rather than as an interface to be implemented.

title: Plugins
heading: 1) Default Behavior
content: you only need to override those methods that you need to customize. you can retain the default behavior of other methods by not altering them.

title: Plugins
heading: 1) Default Behavior
content: each method implementation is intended to be stand-alone and not have side effects or state so when you override one method without changing another this should not have implications.

title: Plugins
heading: 1) Default Behavior
content: extension is accomplished via abstract base classes primarily for the next reason...

title: Plugins
heading: 2) Library Maintenance
content: as hystrix evolves, each of these plugins may gain new methods as new functionality is added or new things are found that need to be customized by users.

title: Plugins
heading: 2) Library Maintenance
content: if hystrix used an interface for this purpose, it would either require a new interface each time new functionality was added (basically an interface per method) or it would necessitate breaking changes for anybody who has implemented the interface. this problem will go away in java 8 when

title: Plugins
heading: 2) Library Maintenance
content: will exist on interfaces, but it will be a while before that is available and this library can choose java 8 as the minimum supported jdk version.

title: Plugins
heading: 2) Library Maintenance
content: hystrix uses abstract base classes so that new optional methods can be added in point releases instead of major releases without breaking existing implementations.
